text: [Music]
hi I'm Chris and I'm going to provide a
brief overview on what a lged database
is a ledger records data changes from an
organization's critical business
applications ledgers are used where
there is a business or regulatory need
to maintain an accurate history of
changes to an application's data for
example tracking the history of credits
and debits in banking transactions
maintaining accurate records of vehicle
ownership or tracing the movement of an
item through a supply chain Network a
ledger database is a new class of
purpose-built database that keeps a
complete and verifiable history of
changes made to an application's data a
ledger database has the following
characteristics it stores the complete
immutable change history of data such
that it can never be overwritten or
deleted it is verifiable as it allows
users to verify the Integrity of
committed data changes and it allow
users to easily access and query the
data history although traditional
databases provide audit and access
control they do not maintain a complete
data lineage that is immutable and
verifiable a ledger database is purpose
built for applications that require
immutability integrity completeness and
verifiability for their data Amazon
Quantum Ledger database or Amazon qldb
is a new purpose built fully managed
Ledger database
so how does Amazon qldb
work the first component of Amazon qldb
is the
journal this journal is an immutable
transaction log where transactions are
appended as blocks of data these blocks
are hash chained together to provide
cryptographic
verifiability you can think of this as
debits and credits being recorded for a
bank account once something is written
to the journal it cannot be changed or
deleted at a later stage in addition the
journal determines current state and
history think of current state as a
table you would query to see the current
account balance think of history as a
table you would query to see the history
of account balances over time you can
remember this as The Ledger comprises
the journal current state and history
and the journal determines the contents
of the current state and
history to make make this concrete let's
look at a simplified example of a
Department of Motor Vehicles or DMV
recording registration and ownership of
cars in this simplified example we have
a single table called the cars table but
there may be many more tables in use in
a real system as you can see in this
example there is the journal which
records transactions the current cars
table and the history cars table let's
see what happens as some changes are
made made the year is 2012 and Tracy
Russell has just bought a new Tesla
Model S and takes it to the DMV to
register it when she completes her
registration the following record is
written to The qldb Ledger first this
transaction will get appended to the
qldb journal as a block of data which
can never be deleted or updated the
journal will then apply a cryptographic
hash function to this block to ensure
that the transaction can be verified at
a lat stage
this function generates a hash which is
appended to the block of data on the
journal any change to that block of data
even a single bit would change the
contents of the hash and be detectable
this transaction then gets updated in
the current cars table which always
keeps the current value of the data
finally the transaction gets indexed in
the history CS table which can be
queried to see how the data has changed
over time now let's assume Tracy sells
her Tesla to Ronnie one year later in
2013 and the DMV needs to update its
record since Amazon QB's Journal is app
pend only this new transaction will get
hash chain to the previous
transaction it's worth noting that in
the journal the previous transaction
will remain intact and will not get
overwritten what's important here is
that the hash from the previous
transaction forms part of the hash of
the new transaction this means that even
a small change in the first transaction
will be easily detectable in the hash in
the second when the new change gets
applied to the current cars table it
will overwrite the previous record since
it maintains the current ownership
record for the Tesla however when this
record gets applied to the history cars
table it now has a total of two records
since it tracks the Tesla's complete
ownership
history when Ronnie sells that Tesla the
same pattern will continue onto the
third buyer the repeats where first the
new record gets hash chained to the
append only Journal then gets updated to
the current cars table and finally
indexed in the history cars
table so this was a quick overview of
what a ledger database is and how it
works I hope you found this useful to
learn more about Amazon QB please visit
our website
